We head back to school tomorrow! The teachers are so excited to greet their students. We know this will be an unusual first day of school. Please remember, we're here for you if you need us!

If you experience a technical issue, please follow these steps to troubleshoot the problem:

--Restart the Chromebook (make sure it turns all the way off before turning back on).
--Quit any unused applications.
--Sign out of an application if it's not working, and sign back in.
--Move closer to your internet router if you are experiencing connectivity issues.
--Turn off any accessibility features, i.e. contrast mode, special cursor that may be set on the Chromebook. These can cause applications to run slow.

If you are still experiencing technical issues after trying the above steps, please submit a Remote Learning Technology Support form at the link below. One of our technology team members will contact you to provide assistance.

Have a great first day!

District 57 announced yesterday that Susannah Wade will fill the new assistant principal position for Lincoln Middle School. She has extensive experience in special education and currently leads the Social and Academic Readiness (SOAR) program at Springman Junior High in Glenview District 34. Susannah will join Randy Steen as assistant principal at Lincoln. The District is replacing the student services coordinator position with this one, in order to handle the significant increase in legal mandates and administrative responsibilities, such as student services support and performance reviews. The addition of this position puts Lincoln on equal footing with neighboring districts, in terms of student-to-administrator and staff-to-administrator ratios.

Principal Paul Suminski and a search committee made up of staff members screened many applicants. We thank them for their diligence in finding such a high-quality candidate. Please join us in welcoming Susannah to District 57! For more details, see Dr. Aumiller's message: https://www.d57.org/SuperintendentsMessage.aspx.

Helpful reminders about doing our best to stay healthy, courtesy of Lincoln nurse Mrs. Smith...

Viruses are a common problem. No one likes being sick. These are things that we should always be doing to prevent becoming sick or making others sick.

-Keep your child home when they are sick. Students need to stay home for 24 hours after they have a fever, and after an episode of vomiting or diarrhea. Do not use medications like ibuprofen or tylenol and send your child to school if your child has a fever.

-Instruct your child to wash hands with soap and water for 20 seconds (sing ABC or Happy Birthday twice) after they go to the bathroom, before and after eating, after blowing their nose or coughing or sneezing.

-If they cannot wash their hands, then they should use hand sanitizer.

-Instruct your child to cough or sneeze into their elbow and away from other people.

-Instruct your child to avoid touching their eyes, nose, mouth.

Work hard to stay well!
